title.value: Population Genomics Approaches for Genetic Characterization of SARS-CoV-2 Lineages
title.justification: The title is directly mentioned at the beginning of the paper as "Population Genomics Approaches for Genetic Characterization of SARS-CoV-2 Lineages."
title.quote: Mostefai F, Gamache I, N’Guessan A, Pelletier J, Huang J, Murall CL, Pesaranghader A, Gaonac’h-Lovejoy V, Hamelin DJ, Poujol R, Grenier J-C, Smith M, Caron E, Craig M, Wolf G, Krishnaswamy S, Shapiro BJ, and Hussin JG (2022) Population Genomics Approaches for Genetic Characterization of SARS-CoV-2 Lineages. Front. Med. 9:826746.

extractions.description: The paper presents a computational framework using population genomics approaches to better understand the genetic diversity and evolution of SARS-CoV-2 lineages during the first year of the COVID-19 pandemic. It utilizes genomic surveillance tools to analyze and evaluate the genetic diversity and lineage trajectories using data from the GISAID database.

type.justification: The study conducts an analysis of genetic diversity using real-world genomic data collected from the GISAID database. It performs various computational experiments such as haplotype network generation, allele frequency trajectory analysis, and principal component analysis using empirical data.
type.quote: We analyzed 329,854 high-quality consensus sequences published in the GISAID database during the pre-vaccination phase.

name.justification: The research focuses on using genomic data to understand the genetic diversity and evolution of SARS-CoV-2 lineages, which is a core aspect of genomics.
name.quote: We present here a set of genomic surveillance tools from population genetics which can be used to better understand the evolution of this virus in humans.

name.justification: The study employs computational methods, including haplotype networks, PCA, and allele frequency calculation, to analyze genomic data, which is a bioinformatics-based approach.
name.quote: This computational framework can help design efficient preventive strategies, identify potentially expanding, divergent lineages and derive a fast response against viral adaptation to future therapeutic strategies.

name.justification: The context of the study revolves around understanding the spread and evolution of the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which directly relates to the field of infectious diseases.
name.quote: This article was submitted to Infectious Diseases - Surveillance, Prevention and Treatment.

name.justification: ImputeCoVNet is explicitly mentioned as a model used for sequence imputation to reduce missing data in the genomic sequences.
name.quote: To help reduce this missing data problem and improve variant assignment, we next imputed all sequences using ImputeCoVNet (17) at positions where the derived allele frequency (DAF) was over 1% during at least one month.

is_contributed.justification: The paper uses ImputeCoVNet, which is already existing model for imputation and not a new contribution by this paper.
is_contributed.quote: We next imputed all sequences using ImputeCoVNet (17) at positions where the derived allele frequency (DAF) was over 1% during at least one month (199 positions).

is_executed.justification: The paper does not mention the specifics of execution regarding GPU or CPU while describing ImputeCoVNet, focusing more on the application and results instead.
is_executed.quote: This novel approach uses a 2D residual neural-network autoencoder that has an accuracy of > 99% and surpasses distance-based methods in terms of computation time (17).

is_compared.justification: The paper does not conduct a numerical comparison of ImputeCoVNet with other models; it simply uses it for processing and analysis without exploring further comparative analysis in terms of performance metrics.
is_compared.quote: This novel approach uses a 2D residual neural-network autoencoder that has an accuracy of > 99% and surpasses distance-based methods in terms of computation time (17).

referenced_paper_title.value: ImputeCoVNet: 2D ResNet autoencoder for imputation of SARS-CoV-2 sequences
referenced_paper_title.justification: The reference title of the paper for ImputeCoVNet is given as "ImputeCoVNet: 2D ResNet autoencoder for imputation of SARS-CoV-2 sequences."
referenced_paper_title.quote: Pesaranghader A, Pelletier J, Grenier JC, Poujol R, Hussin J. ImputeCoVNet: 2D ResNet autoencoder for imputation of SARS-CoV-2 sequences. bioRxiv [Preprint]. (2021).

name.justification: The GISAID database is repeatedly mentioned as the primary source of genomic sequences analyzed in the study.
name.quote: We analyzed 329,854 high-quality consensus sequences published in the GISAID database during the pre-vaccination phase.

referenced_paper_title.value: Data, disease and diplomacy: GISAID’s innovative contribution to global health
referenced_paper_title.justification: This title is referenced to highlight GISAID's contribution to global health, as mentioned in the acknowledgments for their data usage.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Elbe S, Buckland-Merrett G. Data, disease and diplomacy: GISAID’s innovative contribution to global health. Glob Chall. (2017) 1:33–46. doi: 10.1002/gch2.1018
